div.head: What can you do with a TEI XML file?

list.item: The TEI itself doesn't provide you with a toolbox, nor a single do-everything package
The TEI claims to be an application-independent standard: it cannot therefore at the same time propose applications
The Guidelines are designed to give concrete expression of an abstract model of the objects -- mostly textual -- which are of scientific interest to the Humanitires community...
.. but only the members of that community can determine how to process such objects, and hence how to build the tools to make use of them.

div.head: Well, yes, but ..
div.p: The TEI Guidelines s'expriment en XML, comme toute application TEI

list.item: en principe, alors, n'importe quel logiciel conforme au norme XML nous suffirait
mais il faut le construire!

div.p:
La TEI a construit, pour ses propres besoins, un ensemble de feuilles de style XSLT, qui permet:
la génération et la documentation des schémas TEI personalisées ("ODD")
la visualisation des documents TEI, à travers les formats actuellement les plus répandus (XHTML, PDF, Word, Open Office, ePUB...)
une architecture générique pour la transformation entre documents TEI et d'autres formats (Word, OO, Docbook etc.)

div.head: What sort of TEI-XML tools do we need?
div.p:
What might you want to do with a TEI XML document?
create, modify, validate ...
transform, display, visualise ...
search, analyse, mash-up ...
store, preserve, archive, catalogue ...

div.head: Creation and modification of TEI XML documents

list.item: Editors like oXygen are not unique !
See for a range of others, some of them free -- or just ask Google
Documents created with ordinary office tools (Word, Open Office) can be automatically converted to TEI XML, using Oxgarage, oXygen, etc.
Highly structured documents (metadata for example) can be captured by a form and output directly in TEI XML

div.head: Customizing the TEI Stylesheets
div.p: The Stylesheets are designed to be customized...

list.label: Profile
list.item: you can set up a named bunch of transformations and store it as a framework within oXygen (several examples come with the product)
list.label: CSS
list.item: you can use your own CSS stylesheet/s to manage details of how the output will be displayed, on screen or in print
list.label: Stylebear
list.item: you can use the styleBear application to simplify generation of a customized stylesheet
list.label: LaTeX
list.item: LaTeX users can generate high quality PDF output (requires knowledge of LaTeX)

div.head: Digital publishing systems
div.p:
For the management, storage, search, and display of digital TEI editions there is now a variety of software solutions :
Plug-ins for common CMS ( Drupal, Zotero, Omeka)
TEI specific systems (Kiln, TEI Boilerplate, CETEICEAN)
General purpose document management systems (xtf, TEI Publisher)
For the most part, these are systems aimed at web developers, not end-users

div.head: XTF : a digital library creator (for example)

list.item: Extensible Text Framework or XTF () is a collection of server-side scripts from the California Digital Library
If you are already running Apache and Tomcat, and have access to a website, you can set up a default xtf application for TEI files in 5 minutes
(more or less)
If not, the infrastructural overhead may seem prohibitive...

div.head: Some less-demanding tools

list.item: TEI Boilerplate
CETEICEAN
TEI Publisher

div.p: These require knowledge of how to upload pages to a website. That is all.

div.head: TEI Publisher (for example)

list.item: visit and click the try it button
To upload a file, click "login" button (default user: "tei", password: "simple")
scroll down to "Upload" dialogue (bottom right)
Select a TEI XML file from the Work directory (try suprasliensis-tei.xml)
When the file is uploaded, click the goto link to see it displayed in various formats

div.p: To control the way your file is formatted, you need to supply an ODD containing processing instructions : so you need only TEI knowledge

div.head: Bottom line: use the markup!
div.p:
To take full advantage of the XML markup (for example, to search and analyse your documents in terms of their markup) you are usually better off investing in a generic XML database system, such as
baseX
eXist
The solution par excellence for any project managing serious amounts of TEI XML data

div.head: Research tools
div.p: Specialised tools developed for or by particular research communities are also increasingly using TEI as a base format or as an input format:

list.item: textometrie software for lexical statistics
many packages for critical editions
analysis and representation of spoken language
linguistic analysis in general
prosopographic information extracted from archival sources
even the most minimal of approaches makes it possible for you to share your personal analyses of a document
the more elaborate your markup, the more you can do with it
there is however a common core of techniques and facilities: no need to reinvent the wheel
TEI XML empowers the data provider : it's up to you to decide how your materials are exposed and accessed
